Peggy Sue Bodell.action: Decides to break up with Charlie and take a big gamble on her future.
Peggy Sue Bodell.assessment: This decision reflects courage and a willingness to take control of her destiny, showing decisiveness and personal agency, which are positive indicators of competence.

Peggy Sue Bodell.action: Does not respond directly to Richard's proposal to marry him and change her destiny.
Peggy Sue Bodell.assessment: Her omission to respond here may indicate hesitation or uncertainty, suggesting some lack of confidence or decisiveness in this moment.

Peggy Sue Bodell.action: Slams down the book and firmly rejects Richard's marriage proposal, saying 'No! No! No! Peggy Sue got married! Case closed. I don't want to marry anybody. Goodbye Richard.'
Peggy Sue Bodell.assessment: Peggy Sue's rejection is abrupt and dismissive, showing a lack of warmth in this interaction as she shuts down Richard's feelings without much empathy or explanation.

Peggy Sue Bodell.action: Tells Richard he can't go with her because he is going to be Valedictorian.
Peggy Sue Bodell.assessment: This statement is matter-of-fact and does not convey warmth or friendliness; it is more practical and somewhat distancing, indicating a lack of emotional connection in this moment.

Peggy Sue Bodell.action: Slams down the book and decisively says, 'No! No! No! Peggy Sue got married! Case closed. I don't want to marry anybody. Goodbye Richard.'
Peggy Sue Bodell.assessment: This action shows Peggy Sue's ability to make a firm, clear decision and assert her boundaries confidently, indicating a level of decisiveness and self-assurance.

Peggy Sue Bodell.action: Rejects Richard's proposal despite his persistence and reminds him of his goal to be Valedictorian.
Peggy Sue Bodell.assessment: By recognizing Richard's priorities and not allowing emotional pressure to sway her, Peggy Sue demonstrates insight and emotional intelligence, reflecting competent interpersonal awareness.
